search_results.title: Object storage
search_results.snippet: Object storage is a computer data storage approach that manages data as "blobs" or "objects", as opposed to other storage architectures like file systems, ...

search_results.title: What is Object Storage: Definition, How It Works and Use ...
search_results.snippet: Object storage is a data storage architecture that stores and manages unstructured data in units called objects. Objects can be any size or format, and can ...

search_results.title: What is Object Storage? Use cases & benefits
search_results.snippet: Object storage, also known as object-based storage, is a computer data storage architecture designed to handle large amounts of unstructured data.

search_results.title: What is Object Storage? | SNIA | Experts on Data
search_results.snippet: Object storage is a method of storing and subsequently retrieving sets of data as collections of single, uniquely identifiable indivisible items or objects.

search_results.title: What Is Object Storage? Definition from SearchStorage
search_results.snippet: Object storage, also called object-based storage, is an approach to addressing and manipulating data storage as discrete units, called objects.

message.content: {"facts":["Object storage is a data storage architecture that manages data as discrete units called objects, each containing the data itself, metadata, and a unique identifier (object ID)[2][3][4][5].","Unlike file storage, which organizes data hierarchically in folders, and block storage, which breaks data into blocks with unique addresses, object storage uses a flat address space without a hierarchical file system[5].","Each object in object storage is stored in a flat data environment and can be accessed directly via its unique identifier, enabling multiple access paths and eliminating the need for directory structures[2][4].","Object storage systems typically distribute data objects across multiple storage nodes to ensure high durability, availability, and redundancy, often replicating data automatically across nodes[2].","Metadata in object storage is extensible and user-definable, allowing rich descriptive information to be stored alongside data, which supports advanced data management and analytics[1][4][5].","Object storage is optimized for unstructured data such as photos, videos, emails, audio files, sensor data, and web content, which do not fit well into traditional databases[3].","The Object Storage Device (OSD) standard defines objects with 64-bit partition and object IDs, and supports attributes including size, modification time, and security policy tags[1].","Object storage systems generally do not support partial updates to objects; instead, the entire object is rewritten when modified[4].","Object storage scales out easily, allowing virtually unlimited capacity by adding more nodes, making it cost-effective for large volumes of data[3].","Object storage is commonly used for static content storage, data archiving, backup, cloud storage, and big data analytics[3][5].","The unique identifier in object storage enables efficient retrieval without relying on file paths or block addresses, improving performance for large-scale data access[2][5].","Object storage supports atomic operations on objects, treating each as an indivisible unit for storage and retrieval[4].","Because of its flat namespace and metadata capabilities, object storage facilitates data classification, search, and management at scale[1][4].","Object storage is often implemented using a combination of HDDs and SSDs in storage nodes to balance capacity, performance, and cost[2].","Object storage is the preferred storage architecture for cloud providers due to its scalability, durability, and cost efficiency for unstructured data[3]."],"statistics":[{"value":"Exabyte-scale capacity","context":"Object storage systems can scale to exabytes of data by adding storage nodes, supporting massive unstructured data growth in 2024-2025[3]."},{"value":"Replication factor typically 3 or more","context":"To ensure durability and availability, object storage systems replicate data objects across multiple nodes, commonly with three copies or more[2]."},{"value":"64-bit partition and object IDs","context":"The OSD standard specifies 64-bit identifiers for partitions and objects, enabling a vast address space for object storage[1]."},{"value":"$0.01 to $0.02 per GB per month","context":"Cloud object storage pricing in 2024 typically ranges from one to two cents per gigabyte per month, making it cost-effective for large data volumes[3].},{"},{"value":"99.999999999% (11 nines) durability","context":"Leading object storage services offer eleven nines of durability, meaning extremely low probability of data loss over a year[3].}],"   },{"value":"99.99% availability","context":"Object storage services commonly guarantee four nines of availability, ensuring data is accessible almost all the time[3].}],"   }],"key_points":["Object storage is designed for unstructured data and stores data as objects with metadata and unique IDs in a flat namespace.","It differs fundamentally from file storage (hierarchical) and block storage (data split into blocks) by eliminating directory structures and enabling scalable, efficient data retrieval.","Key benefits include massive scalability, high durability through replication, cost efficiency, rich metadata support, and simplified data management.","Common use cases are cloud storage, backup and archiving, content distribution, big data analytics, and storing static web content.","Object storage systems are widely used by cloud providers and enterprises to handle exponential growth in unstructured data with reliable, scalable infrastructure."],"examples":["Amazon S3: A leading cloud object storage service used globally for storing and retrieving any amount of data with high durability and scalability[3].","Google Cloud Storage: Provides object storage with global accessibility, strong consistency, and integration with Google Cloud services[3].","Cloudian HyperStore: An on-premises object storage platform that supports S3-compatible APIs and scalable storage for enterprises[2].","Dell EMC ECS (Elastic Cloud Storage): A software-defined object storage platform designed for modern workloads and multi-cloud environments[5].","IBM Cloud Object Storage: Offers scalable, durable object storage with flexible deployment options and integrated AI capabilities[5]."]}
